40032092.review:
Ever wanted to play a game that mixed excessive violence with wackadoo 90's humor? If so, well, then this is the game for you.

Harvester tells the story of Steve, a young man who wakes up in a surreal 1950's town with no memory of who he is or where he is. Such mystery! As Steve is guided through the town of Harvest, he slowly uncovers the dark and dastardly forces at work and how he's involved with all of it...

In case the trailer didn't clue you in, and if you've never heard of this game before, Harvester is notorious for its violent content. But straight up, this game is no where near as shocking as it was when it came out in the 90's. The special effects in the cutscenes range from passable 80's practial effects to Microsoft paint doodles. And the violence is the focal selling point of Harvest because it really doesn't have much else going for it. 

Ever play a point and click before? Then you've played this. If not, you point, you click, things happen. The problem with this - and especially with Harvester - is that oftentimes the things you need to interact with are so miniscule, so tiny on the screen, that it becomes almost impossible to know what to do next. It doesn't help that because 90% of the visuals in Harvester are super grainy and pixelated; trying to find key items or objects to interact with in the environments becomes extremely difficult. But as you manage to find things and use them you'll learn that 75% of Harvester is just that: clicking on stuff. There aren't any real puzzles, the little combat it has is stiff and unfair, and most of the game takes place in the same few screens. 

So why am I recommending it? Because if you play it with a guide (which I did), you can strap yourself in for a wacky ride. The content is graphic, but stupid and over the top. It's a satire/commentary on the rise of graphic violence in pop culture that dominated the 90's. If something could go from 0-10 in a second, Harvester takes it to 11. The actual story itself kept my interest enough to see where it would go and the ending was stupidly satisfying. I can't reiterate this enough: play this with a guide. No shame. It's not that long, it's dated, but it offers goofy thrills if you're willing to give it some leeway.

39241711.review:
When I bought Harvester, I bought it simply because I enjoy the horror genre, and because I saw some amusing snippets of FMVs from the game. I didn’t have many expectations, other than hearing that the game was extremely gory, disgusting, and funny. Seeing as all of these things appeal to me (and it was relatively cheap), I decided to give it a go.

Right off the bat, I warn that this game is NOT for everyone, in fact, I believe a lot of people will hate this game. It is very retro (at times outdated), time-consuming, the puzzles are sometimes ridiculously complex, and this game can be downright frustrating (e.g. I started playing  the game, got an hour deep into it, died, and Oh-Silly-Modern-Convenienced-Me, forgot that AUTOSAVE did not exist in the 90s, and was brought back to the very beginning of the game). All that being said, however, I absolutely loved this game.

Its vintage graphics have a lovable charm, the FMVs were outrageously fun, the dialogue was humorous (and sometimes surprisingly deep), and overall I enjoyed playing. Even when I was cursing in frustration. The shock value gore was, admittedly, not as “disgusting” as I was expecting, but was still good fun and good for a laugh. I found rather than the gore being disturbing, sometimes the atmosphere and content was the more unsettling of the two.

As for the puzzles, I am not a “gamer”, I am not seasoned in virtual puzzles, and quite frankly, I was lost very early on. When I played with a friend who DOES consider himself a gamer, he was also lost. But! Do not fear, a walkthrough exists on the internet and helped immensely.

Overall, this game is now one of my favourites and I make a point to play others of the “90s point ‘n’ click horror” genre. I would recommend this game to anyone who is charmed by retro graphics, enjoys dark comedy, and is willing to use a walkthrough to get them through.

38829336.review:
Harvester: A deeply entertaining ghost of the FMV Craze

Whenever a new technology comes out into the mainstream, you bound to get some experimental stuff. Movies that used color and sound to express new feelings and ideas, music that used synthesizers to push boundries. When games get new technology they don't know what to do with, you get Harvester. Harvester is half Point-and-click FMV Madness and half side scrolling beat-em-up with even more madness. It's what happens when you write a game story after marathoning the entire first season of the Twilight Zone while high on ketamine.

The story is probably the most entertaining part of the game, as it does attempt to gently ease you in to the mania of Harvester. Your name is Steve, you've awoken in the town of Harvest, you have one week to join the mysterious Lodge. The whole town of Harvest is like if you let William S. Burroughs write the scripts to Leave It To Beaver, it's 50's America with a bag of dark twists thrown on it for good measure. The town has a missile base run by a batshit Air Force General who rigged the launch control to a literal big red button, there's a mysteriously large amount of random hobo deaths and of course, the Lodge that you have to get into.

Gameplay is a 50/50 split between the story's main arcs. The first half is a stock standard point-and-click game where you can either do the story missions or google all the weird conversation trees you can start. And that's not even counting how weird some of the actual trees you use to get items are. I highly reccomend you get a basic walkthrough for the early half because the puzzles the game throws at you are some of the most obtuse I've seen in a game. The other half is a broken and yet still entertaining beat-em-up as Steve navigates the Lodge. How entertaining? It's where you fight bellhops, walking pieces of ancient art, chess pieces and yourself. Also there are more puzzles, so do keep that walkthrough on standby.

Harvester is like a really entertaining B movie and I have no idea if that's what the devs intended it to be or not. Regardless, I can't help but reccomend this game just because it's entertaining in the depths of its madness. One can't help but laugh as you watch Steve just act so normally in a town that is definitely not in the realm of normal. It's a game where you electrocute a random Italian barber and his pet demonic sheep so you can steal his prized barber's pole, you can inadvertantly cause World War III and global annihalation for accidently talking about llamas, and where you solve a puzzle by beating a guy at chess so an axe falls on his head and reveals a key hidden in his head. Utter madness, but enjoyable madness.

37818712.review:
TL;DR version: As a very confusing PSA once said, "This is your brain on drugs." The same quote can be applied here, only if your brain was on drugs and you had a very traumatic childhood. Cheesy FMV graphics, very basic point-and-click controls; what really makes it a great play is the story, characters, and environment. Solid 8/10. Kids, stay in school, eat your vegetables, and save this game for when you're older, mmkay? Maybe stay away from whatever this game's developers were on, too. Weed is good enough.

Now for the full review, let us first address the elephant in the room: this game probably no longer possesses the title of "the most violent adventure game of all time." So if you're like me, a jaded 3dg3l0rd looking to push yourself to disturbing new boundaries and discover just how far you're willing to go, this game probably won't satisfy that perverse itch much. However, I don't consider myself disappointed since the game offers up more than only people bursting like gore-filled balloons when you stab them. (Yeah, just as a heads-up: while this may no longer be the most violent adventure game of all time, it's definitely still not for the kiddies. Unless you were brought up by Charles Manson, in which case: charge forth, young psychopath; this will probably feel right at home to you.)

"What could possibly be in this game that would cause a reviewer to compare it to the thoughts you have while on questionable substances combined with the acts of a murderous cult leader?" the 25% of you who wandered onto this Steam page fully blind may ask. Well, I'll do my best to break it down for ye wee few without giving away any spoilers.

For starters, what's this game about? You play as a man named Steve who wakes up one morning to find that not only has he lost his memory, but home and the people in it are all a little "off." And by "off," I mean that the entire town of Harvest is inhabited by exaggerated 1950's charicatures, each with a rather psychotic and sociopathic edge. As it turns out, Steve only has six days to uncover the mysteries of this surreal little town and find a way to escape back to normal society, all with an ominous-sounding blood drive looming on the seventh day.

This game is bizarre, to say the least. It does a good job of making sure nothing feels right from the second you enter the world, though I think the lovably outdated FMV style graphics and slightly off-kilter soundtrack do a lot to build the weird atmosphere. It keeps you on your toes and questioning everything, since nothing about this game is predictable if you're a first-time player. It's rather like being in an excessively dark, twisted version of Alice in Wonderland: nothing is logical or makes sense, and the world and its inhabitants follow their own set of senseless rules that endlessly baffle, annoy, and even horrify your main character. Yet, much like Alice in Wonderland it manages to find its own strange balance in that the world is surprisingly well fleshed-out (no pun intended, har har): there are no inconsistencies to the world's logic, or lack thereof, and nobody acts out of character. This, combined with the everyman protagonist, make the kooky environment just grounded enough that you can follow along, while also being wild enough to keep you intrigued.

Like with most FMV games, the performances given by the actors range from patchy to perfect. However, if anything I feel like the uncanny blend of mediocre and semi-professional acting works in this game's favor. These characters are supposed to be strange, sometimes to the point where you begin to question whether or not they're even people, so the unusual behavior is only fitting and helps add to the purposeful unease the game works so hard to instill in you, the player. A lot of the dialogue and cutscenes will make your skin crawl and send a deep discomfort twisting in your belly.

Unfortunately, the playthrough does get a little marred by its dated, simplistic mechanics, particularly in the last third which is oddly combat heavy. Sorry, DigiFX Interactive, but it's just not all that interesting to walk back and forth click-spamming literally two-dimensional baddies. What makes the game so fun, interesting, and unique is interacting with the wacky characters and seeing the effects your actions have on Harvest. Take that away and a little of its charm is simply lost. However, it doesn't render the game unplayable by any means and doesn't serve to dampen much of the experience, so this is more of a nitpick than anything else.

Believe it or not, this game is actually far smarter than you would expect. Granted, the commentary and message it's trying to get across are somewhat jumbled and hard to interpret, but when you play you can tell that a lot of effort and attention went into making each detail precise and perfect. It's obvious that the people who made it did so with a great deal of loving care, which is something that I feel is rare and precious, particularly in a medium that can make modern Hollywood's oversaturation seem tame by comparison. It's impressive what they managed to accomplish with limited technology and a budget that one imagines was probably less than overly generous.

The only thing I really have left to say is that this is not for the politically correct at heart. Seriously, if this game was released today, Tumblrarians and hysterical mothers would be out in full-force boycotting any store selling it, burning every copy they could lay their hands on, and marching in neat little circles outside the developers' houses, screaming lynch mob-style threats. In my opinion, this game is broadly offensive to all and doesn't really focus on targeting any one group in particular, so no demographic comes across as hated or particularly contemptuous; rather all are worthy of judgement in their own ways. Speaking as an LGBT+ Tumblrarian who's quite fond of keeping things fairly PC, I honestly admire this balls-to-the-wall, "0 **** given about your sensitivities" attitude, and rejoice that this game came out in the 90's when it was more acceptable to call out the flaws in both minority and majority groups alike.

Overall, an intriguing experience, and one that I would highly recommend for the brave, weird-seeking, and strong-stomached among you.

Things that have occurred to me since playing Harvester..

1. I now loathe the word "meat"
2. Punching people rarely solves problems
3. You should not talk to people in the military who have no legs (they invariably shoot you)
4. The 90's were not very progressive
5. I love this game

Yes, it is very odd. 
Yes, it is a child of the 90's and if this was released today, the PC (Political correctness) brigade would be out in force, demanding it be burnt. 
Yes, the FMV's can sometimes be rather intrusive, but these are all small niggles. 

The game itself is surprising large and deep, with certain things very easy to miss/overlook. The story, while exceedingly bizarre, does draw you in, making you want to find out what happens next. The characters range from the normal to plainly mad, which all add to the mystery and intrigue. The conversation method can be rather odd, in that options you initially had, but never follow, will mysteriously disappear. If your memory is good (or you have the foresight to note things down on notepad), you can get back to them later on, but I found myself missing large chunks of conversation because of this. Some characters will also stop speaking to you out of the blue. That being said however, It's all part of the nature and charm of the game, and it doesn't put me off in the least.

In Short, If you enjoy point'n'clicks and don't mind the abscure, obscene and plain ol' weird, then this is perfect for you!

34832755.review:
No es para todos los públicos. Creo que es el juego más sórdido al que he jugado en toda mi vida. Al menos ahora mismo no se me ocurre otro que se le acerque. También tiene mérito ofrecer toda esa violencia siendo una aventura gráfica pura y dura. Eso sí, a mí me ha encantado.

Es un point&click en FMV como corresponde a 1994, pero en este caso, por su carácter de serie B, ha envejecido bien. Normalmente las producciones de este estilo que eran “serias” ya destilaban un aroma kitsch a los pocos años de su lanzamiento y hoy en día son consideradas como algo simplemente ridículo por la mayoría de jugadores. Este no es el caso, porque al igual que ocurre con las películas de terror de bajo presupuesto, su cutrez no hace más que darle encanto. Lo mismo pasa con el doblaje. Viene con voces en castellano y ese toque español tan noventero con sus limitaciones técnicas, lejos de dañarlo, lo convierte en un juego más entrañable.

Se juega como una aventura gráfica tradicional y desde el principio puedes recorrer libremente todo el mapa. Es un pueblo con sus calles, casas, establecimientos y un montón de personajes, que si bien no llegan a ser rednecks, son ciudadanos norteamericanos de los años cincuenta tan cortos en su forma de entender el mundo, aficiones y opiniones políticas, como sórdidos, retorcidos y malas personas. Creo que es mejor no contar nada más sobre ellos ni sobre la historia. Solo diré que cada diálogo y cada descripción de los objetos son dignos de captura. También tiene escenas de vídeo bastante potentes, de esas que no se ven en un videojuego. Ni en los de antes, ni mucho menos en los de ahora.

Hay que aclarar que no se trata de violencia ni barbaridades gratuitas. Todo tiene sentido y un por qué. Si fuera un periodista de videojuegos gafapaster de la nueva ola, os diría que es un ensayo filosófico sobre la violencia y los medios de comunicación y sus influencias en la sociedad norteamericana de los años noventa, ampliando su crítica a la política, la educación y las tradiciones culturales y familiares. Disparando a bocajarro desde el propio medio tantas veces blanco de críticas injustificadas por parte de estos estamentos, antes cazadores y ahora cazados, con influencias de Cioran, Hideshi Hino, y Harmony Korine.

Pero no me da la cabeza para tanto. Compradlo, que además es barato.

33772265.review:
En Harvester seremos Steve Mason, joven de aproximadamente 20 años quien despierta algo agitado tras sonar la alarma de su despertador. Sin embargo, jamás hubiese imaginado que lo que vivió en su pesadilla fue sin duda más agradable que la realidad que tendría que enfrentar. No pasa mucho hasta que nos damos cuenta de que vivimos con una extraña familia en un pueblo llamado Harvest (que parece un calco del lado oscuro de Twin Peaks), y que para colmo tenemos amnesia y no recordamos quién somos ni dónde estamos. Por si fuese poco, todo el pueblo parece haber complotado para tomarnos el pelo. Todos excepto la hija de nuestros vecinos, quien además es nuestra futura esposa y también sufre de amnesia. ¿Qué hacer ante tal situación? Todas las respuestas parecen estar en la logia, una extraña organización local a la que los pueblerinos parecen guardarle una fascinación irracional. A consecuencia, nuestro objetivo será unirnos como sea. El precio a pagar será alto. 

Y luego de la intro llega el momento de poner manos a la obra. Se nos presenta una interfaz point & click de lo más usual. Podremos mover el puntero e interactuar con los escenarios para mover al personaje a un punto particular o para activar puntos sensibles. Lo que no es tan corriente aquí es que no se nos permite inspeccionar los objetos del inventario como en casi cualquier aventura. Pero curiosamente desde este menú si se nos trasmite el estado de salud del protagonista ¿Cómo? Si, Harvester incluye secuencias arcade donde el combate es crucial y nuestro protagonista puede morir. A diferencia de otros juegos del género, este no recurre a puzles complejos para aumentar su dificultad; más bien lo hace a través de su no-linealidad, la repetición de acciones impensadas y la posibilidad de morir. 

El resto de sus elementos jugables son más clásicos. Dispondremos de un mapa de todo el pueblo que nos indicará el lugar al que nos podemos dirigir. Visitaremos así distintas tiendas, edificios administrativos y las residencias de los pueblerinos. El interactuar con otros personajes dará lugar a diálogos de múltiples opciones. Los temas disponibles para abordar y las respuestas que proporcionen los interlocutores cambiarán de forma dinámica dependiendo de cuando hables con ellos. De todas formas, me veo obligada a citar un punto molesto de estas conversaciones: se hace muy fácil perdernos partes de las charlas ya que una vez seleccionado un tema de conversación, los demás temas no aparecerán nuevamente a menos que el escogido se relacione con los demás. El mismo juego ofrece una solución a esto y es la de dejarnos tipear el nombre del tema del que queremos dialogar en un espacio de la interfaz de diálogo. Se agradece la opción pero no puedo dejar de considerarla innecesaria y rebuscada. Al fin y al cabo se hace bastante molesto andar recordando o adivinando sobre qué temas quiere hablar tal personaje. 

A pesar de ser un poco retorcido en mecánicas jugables, su argumento es lo suficientemente interesante e inteligente como para querer seguir jugándolo en todo momento. Incluso hoy en día, casi veinte años después de su lanzamiento, sigue sorprendiendo y divirtiendo por igual. ¿Cómo lo logra? Gracias a estar construido como una crítica abierta a la violencia en sociedad; una parodia cínica y sin escrúpulos que nos confirma que la forma elegida por muchos para responder a la violencia es con más violencia. Tanto el guión como la construcción de los personajes se desarrollan de forma tal que sirven a dicha crítica en todo momento.Por consiguiente, casi cualquier elemento narrativo del título resultará chocante y hasta ofensivo para casi cualquier ser humano civilizado. Encontraremos decenas de diálogos sobre los que será imposible no pensar "¿Realmente acaban de decir eso?" y ni hablar de las situaciones planteadas: todas una sátira en si mismas. De todas formas, quiero aclarar que su enfoque principal es humorístico. Es crudo y negro como pocos videojuegos, pero no deja de ser un entretenimiento en ningún momento por lo que quienes disfruten de un humor más negro, además de sorprenderse con la inteligencia y el rigor de su guión, realmente se la van a pasar riendo.

El apartado gráfico ya se mostraba atrasado para su época por lo que hoy en día habrá quienes no puedan verlo con buenos ojos. Se presenta como una suerte de FMV donde las animaciones in-game son más bien precarias y los fondos, a pesar de ser fotorealistas, en muchas ocasiones no exhiben gran nivel de detalle. Por lo tanto, uno debe prepararse para una aventura con mucho pixel-hunting donde muchas veces no será fácil dar con los objetos interactivos.

Contrariamente a lo que muchos puedan esperar de él, Harvester trae consigo algo más que una dosis de violencia y buen humor negro. Tanto su guión como su jugabilidad son absolutamente divertidos y constituyen un gran soplo de aire fresco, no sólo dentro del género de horror sino además dentro de la aventura gráfica en sí. Es un título atemporal ¡Único! ¿Qué mejor forma de cortar la racha de videojuegos de terror clónicos si no es con la resurrección de esta joya antigua que combina lo mejor de Stephen King y David Lynch?

Nota: 9/10

So harvester is an interesting game that is different from anything else I played. Not because of the gameplay, but the subject matter. This is an adventure game for the first 2/3rd's of it. The game uses FMV videos so you will see very campy acting from human characters, however I think this fits perfectly with the games unsettling tone. The sound is fine, nothing stands out, but nothing bad does either, it's perfectly fine. 

The gameplay starts as a point and click game and a good one. You click to navigate and to pick up and use objects. It has nice puzzles and although it can be hard to know where to go next, the town is small enough that it won't be for long. The last 1/3rd of the game is the stumbling block though, as it focuses on action. It's really bad. It felt too random, like I wasn't in control of the outcome. To be fair some of the best puzzles are in the last parts of the game, I just wish it wasn't bogged down by awful combat. 

The story is the real star here. It was so interesting that I kept going even in the worst parts of the game. Everyone was weird in their own way and I really wanted to know why, as the town gives a weird vibe from the moment you step out of your room. And without spoiling anything the game dives into subject matter that can get...uncomfortable. While the game isn't the goriest ever, it was still hard to get through some of it. But it wasn't for tacky shock value. It's trying to make a point. And that point is probably more relevent now than it was when the game first came out.

Overall this game is worth playing for the story. Just know that this game will test your will power because of the content and your patience because of the last 1/3rd of the gameplay  

8/10

32782154.review:
[b]FMVs, gore & violence, '90s[/b]

Ah, the good old '90s! Full Motion Videos were a new thing: the first time I saw them was when playing Command & Conquer. They gave you a movie-like experience (at the time these videos had an extremely low resolution, though). The way it affected the point-and-click adventure game genre was the inclusion of a lot of cutscenes in between stages and regardless of how serious the characters looked they were ultimately acting in a very cheesy way. It was as if you were taking part in a B movie.

[b]"You killed your family?"
"What of it?"[/b]

Harvester is on par with games such as Phantasmagoria 1-2 or Dark Seed 1-2. These were all games that tried to look like an interactive movie experience. And while Dark Seed introduced the unique vision of H.R. Giger into the gaming world Phantasmagoria and Harvester showed you something violent, something brutal that nobody had ever seen before. Your protagonist could die in many ways depending on the trap or enemy it faced. These cutscenes always depicted something horrible, something extremely gory. 

[b]"You always were a kidder, Steve!"[/b]

Our protagonist, Steve, wakes up one day only to find himself in the '50s. He does not recognise the town of Harvest; in fact, he has no idea who the people are in his house. As much as they claim to be his parents or younger brother he has no recollection of them. Amnesia or not, Steve has a big day ahead of him: he is soon to marry Stephanie and just as the future in-laws Steve's parents, too, expect him to join the Lodge. The Lodge is where the Order of the Harvest Moon is found and in order to join them Steve must complete the process of initiation. This consists of several tasks that are, unfortunately, violent things. These initially seem to be just pranks but will soon get out of control.

[b]"This town won't be the same without DNA's Diner. Or DNA, for that matter!"[/b]

Once we leave an establishment the game shows us the map of Harvest. We are free to move anywhere we please. As certain activities are completed the game switches the day-night cycle. It's always worth returning to the same spot to speak with the same people. We can find out how they feel about the things happening in town and each day brings us closer to the Lodge and a truly horrifying, long sequence of gore-fest. During my playthrough the Lodge always reminded me of Twin Peaks' Black Lodge as some of the dialogues were similarly cryptic, nonsense mumbo-jumbo.

[b]"What're you doing, Steve?"[/b]
[b]"Playing Harvester."[/b]

Beside picking up items, using them, solving puzzles, interacting with people we also fight others ranging from people to the supernatural. A handful of melee weapons as well as guns are available for us to do so - these sequences can easily make us lose the game. Our health indicator should be checked manually by opening up our inventory. Remember: this was the '90s so no checkpoint system existed; a lost battle means game over once and for all. Make sure you save regularly especially in the last half an hour or so.

[b]"You've always been a kidder, Steve."[/b]

Although it received mixed reviews 20 years ago Harvester managed to become a cult classic. Frankly, I don't know if I should recommend this to kids from the new millennium. This is a must if you were born in the '80s and played many games in the '90s. You can give this one a try if you love point-and-click games and would like to get to know some of the gory ones from the '90s.

32683779.review: I'm so intrigued by these incredibly unique cult-classic 90's games. Whether it be Postal, Harvester, Dark Seed 1 and 2, Sanitarium, IHNMAIMS and so on.  The whole game reeks of this seemingly innocent 50's atmosphere, but beneath the surface, theres much more than meets the eye. Basically coming off as an overly edgy Twin Peaks, chock full of gore, some much needed 90's angst, and hilariously outdated social commentary, which is seemingly a total recipe for disaster, ends up being the most enjoyable and entertaining point & click I've ever played. From the get-go, literally the first conversation you get engaged in, just immediately shoves some not-so-subtle social commentary right in your face and forces you to choke it down. You converse with your supposed "family", complaining of amnesia, but Steve being the kidder he is, is ignored and pointed in the direction of the lodge. On your way, you meet a quirky and demented cast of characters that (barely) help you along the way. Excuse me for my lack of information, but it's one of those game that you absolutely have to experience for yourself. Reading a synopsis or watching a walkthrough doesn't serve it justice in the slightest. It's a psychotic, disturbing and hilarious mess that everyone must experience.

29855284.review:
Una aventura de las que probé basándome en algunos comentarios que leí sobre ella, donde a pesar de pasar desapercibida en su momento merece la pena si no eres de mente y estómago sensible. 

Una de las cosas que más llama la atención en Harvester es la cantidad malsana de gore, visceras, situaciones bastante cochambrosas alimentadas por el morbo que representan, pero esto es uno de los detalles que la hacen tan diferente a cualquier otra aventura que hayamos jugado. Acudiendo al celuloide, podemos decir que se trata de un cruce entre una película de David Lynch (Twin Peaks) y una de las primeras que hacía el ahora muy popular Peter Jackson, con cuatro dolares, llenas de vísceras pero a la vez divertidísimas (Bad Taste, Braindead). Vísceras, violencia, gore, sexo sádico, asesinos en serie, mutilaciones..., ya digo que hay que tener fuerte estómago y cero prejuicios ante muchas de las situaciones que se dan en el juego.

Aclarado el primer punto, el argumento, esencial en toda aventura gráfica que se precie; se recurre al tema de la amnesia, donde encarnamos a Steve Mason, que se encuentra en un pequeño poblado de la América profunda, rodeado por seres a cada cual más perturbado, y que al parecer iba a casarse con Stephanie, la otra protagonista que parece encontrarse en una situación similar a Steve. Para ello debe unirse a la misteriosa Logia de la Hermandad de la Cosecha de la Luna, una misteriosa institución de la que nadie forma parte pero todos quieren, así debemos cumplir una serie de objetivos para ingresar y desentrañar el misterio que asola a Harvest y sus protagonistas.

Nos movemos en tercera persona por los entornos renderizados como en cualquier aventura de hacer click, examinando objetos, utilizando algunos y charlando con los personajes del juego. En esta parte, cabe destacar el elenco de tipos estereotipados al máximo, cada uno mostrando lo peor de la sociedad norteamericana en alguna de sus facetas, un guardia xenófobo, un actor racista, amas de casa sádicas...lo mejor de cada casa vamos. Las conversaciones son delirantes, idas de olla tremendas, divertidas y malsanas. Es importante hablar con todos los personajes y tener cuidado con lo que decimos, porque aquí morir es extremadamente fácil, una mala respuesta y nos pegan un tiro.

La otra parte del juego tiene elementos de acción, con una gran cantidad de armas desperdigadas debemos hacer frente a algunos enemigos que aparecen, de diseños extrañísimos y originales, otros nos los buscaremos nosotros con nuestras respuestas; el resultado es curioso, moviéndonos por la pantalla para aporrear al enemigo o dispararle, como una pelea de cangrejos, con situaciones desternillantes, y como reitero hay gran variedad de armas a nuestra disposición, incluso de fuego con munición limitada, además tenemos un indicador de vida que debemos vigilar.

En cuanto al apartado técnico hay que tener en cuenta que estamos ante un juego del año 1995, está realizado con actores reales en FMV y a veces tiene problemas con configuraciones modernas, se ven muchos píxeles y hay pocas animaciones, algo ortopédico pero igualmente disfrutable sin duda.
El sonido es normal, aunque hay algunas melodías interesantes que ayudan a la inmersión en la trama, además cuenta con voces y subtítulos en castellano, con gran calidad en los actores de doblaje.

En definitiva, nos encontramos ante una aventura única, desternillante en muchas ocasiones, muy bizarra y llena de violencia que no gustará a los sensibleros, pero que hará disfrutar a todo aquel con mente abierta y que no le asuste lo macabro, hay que dejar a un lado su apartado técnico y limitaciones que pueda tener y embarcarse en ella pues el tiempo que dura merece la pena.

NOTA 8/10

29606863.review:
"Harvester" is a classic adventure point and click game from 1996. You play as Steve, 18-year-old who wakes up in weird 1950s town of Harvest with amnesia.

The game was shocking in 1996 and is still somewhat shocking today. It's a cheesy satire on violence in media and video games. It's weird and full of bizarre characters. But if you can accept 1996 FMV graphics and you like point-and-click games, you can really enjoy this game.

Responsive interface, good acting and voice acting (remember, it's satire, it's supposed to be strangely cheesy!) and LOTS of locations to explore - full recommendation.

GAMEPLAY 8/10
GRAPHICS 7/10
AUDIO 9/10
STORY 8/10

29575279.review:
"The most violent adventure game of all time" Yup this game live up to its reputation.

A great humoristique satire on the greath american culture of the 1950.
You can kill anyone in the game (If you want to kill your anoying brother you can just beware of the Electric hair). 
You basicaly have the freedom to wreck a havoc in your town which is a neat feature that was and is rare in the point and click genre.
The character are greath and terrifying in there crazy way, from Steve hysterical mother to his insane pedofile step father every caracter take his crazy role seriously which make the experience some much more memorable. 

The Fmv video feel cheap and unessasry (But that not a huge complaint since it a promblem with most FMV games).
The voice acting is solid in it's gameplay segements.
Dialogue choice don't offer much diversity at all. When taking a critical decision most of the time the outcomes stays the same which is disappointing, more variety would have been appreciated. 
Some of the violent encounter that are render in the FMV video format could've been more memorable whit the use of more practical effect.
Story wise it does start strong but sadly stumble in it's last act.

I can definitely understand why harvester has a fanbase and deserve more appreciation for what is has achieved.

8/10 Verdict: It is not a perfect game, surrounded by design flaws and some aspect of the gameplay have not aged well since it's 1996 release. But the experience was so enjoyable that I can easily recommend Harvester in 2017.

Vecchissima avventura in FMV, genere che negli anni 90 spopolava e che oramai è andato perduto.
Tecnicamente il titolo è invecchiato malissimo e non può essere altrimenti visto che parliamo della versione originale resa compatibile con i modermi SO tramite DosBox (personalmente ho avuto problemi usando Windows 10) ma a livello di "storia" Harvester può ancora dire la sua.
La violenza e gli argomenti scabrosi presenti mantengono, tutt'oggi, quasi invariata la propria carica destabilizzatrice facendo del gioco, nonostante gli anni sul groppone, un'esperienza relativamente forte.
Parlando del gameplay durante l'avventura si alternano enigmi piuttosto logici ad altri tirati troppo per i capelli oltre ad un abuso piuttosto fastidioso del pixel hunting, che ai tempi era quasi la norma ma oggi fa pensare solamente ad un goffo tentativo per allungare la longevità.
Sono presenti anche delle fasi action, quasi da picchiaduro a scorrimento orrizontale, che (opinione personale) non solo non aggiungono nulla di valido al gioco ma sono realizzate anche in maniera troppo dozzinale ed imprecisa.
L'ultima parte del gioco è rovinata proprio da questi pseudo combattimenti tanto che la fase finale si gioca giusto per vedere la conclusione.
Gioco consigliato, tuttavia, perchè rimane una pietra miliare nella storia dei videogiochi horror e la trama resta molto godibile con diverse trovate grottesche e splatter che rimangono impresse.

Mr Lynch? Meet Mr Waters. Well met, sir!

   You want crazy?  Boy, have WE got some crazy for you!  You want gore, black humour, social satire?  Well, we got a whole lot of that too!  Welcome to the wonderful, wacky world of Harvester, where nothing is quite what it seems, and that's possibly a good thing, 'cause no community could be as sickly-sweet as this one PRETENDS to be... 
 
   It's a point-and-click adventure, and a defiantly "old-school" one at that.  Well, I say "defiantly", but really it's old-school because it's, well...OLD (1996 to be exact)!  It's also a tad overpriced considering, but if you've a taste for the tasteless and the wilfully weird, you could do much worse than to pick this up in one o' them sale thingamajigs.  

   It's dated some, sure, but it's still every bit as sick - and, in its own odd way, witty - as the day it first bloodily burst forth from its Mama's womb.  Definitely not for the squeamish, or easily offended.  Good thing mah Ma dropped me on mah head when I was a young'un...
 
Verdict: 8.5/10.
 
(PS Like almost all old-school "adventure" games, you're gonna need a walkthrough to get through this one. Me, I barely got through Days One and Two without cheating, and pretty much watched the rest on YouTube. Obscure puzzles just ain't my forte, I'm afraid to say. An intriguing adventure game....lots of mystery and intrigue, good plot...

But the awful acting lets it down, as does the fact you end up with dozens of items in your inventory and end up using everything with everything to try and make something happen....

Oh, and you can die, simply by clicking on the wrong thing or not doing something earlier in the game you had no idea was important.

And...for some reason, half way through it suddenly adds a really awful combat system. Doesn't matter how good you are at puzzles, I hope your reflexes are good!

The last third or so of the game is just a random series of unconnected rooms. The ending...sort of explains why this is the case, but it just looks like they threw in all the loose-ends and half-finished ideas they had floating around the office, with no attempt at linking them together.

If they'd ditched the combat, had the game remove items as soon as they were useless to you....and given you more warning before you do something fatal, it could be up there with Sanitarium or possibly the first Phantasmagoria. It would never be on the level of the Gabriel Knight games as far as plot goes, but at least it would have been enjoyable.

As it is, it's more frustrating than anything else.

26461314.review:
I am deciding to rewrite this review to a full scale review. There will be spoilers ahead so be warned


Now Harvester is an old Dos game from the "weird" era of PC gaming where the games weren't limiting themselves from offensive content to reach a mass audience like they are today. Games like Fallout and Phantasmagoria really worked to bring a creepy realism to the game. Harvester clearly does the same and quite well to be honest. The atmosphere is quite creepy and character interaction feels real yet slightly off (as intended,) and the town, which is named Harvest, feels like it's something out of a parody. The game itself goes from weird and zany to downright creepy. 

Let's get on to the story and there are heavy spoilers within, the story itself is quite well written in the beginning, and the end but the middle feels slow in my opinion. It starts with your character, Steve,  being an amnesiac, people don't believe it because "You always were a kidder." You find out you are engaged to a woman named Stephanie. Talking to the townsfolk, you find information about this so called "Order of the Harvest Moon" which most people just call the Lodge. They implore you to join as if your life depends on it. You have to join for the story to progress of course, and in order to get into the lodge you must pass these daily tests, starting at harmless pranks like scratching a car to burning down a woman's diner, quite the escalation. You can check on your bride-to-be and tell her what's going on, yet eventually she is murdered with only her spinal cord left behind along with a lodge invitation, You gain entry to the lodge, after giving the Sergant of Arms Stephanie's spinal cord, and the surreal elements of the game start to pick up again. You go through trials, killing monsters, learning about life and death along the way.

This game is quite creepy, and is actually quite fun but there are some problems with it. As i mentioned the story loses itself somewhere in the middle, a lot of the well written dialogue and character development can be completely avoided, even parts of the game can be avoided and sometimes I feel like they didn't even really program them into the game. This is a point-and-click, and wonky at that. It could be this version of the game, I've head the GOG version is much better. I would recommend this game if you're looking for something to really give you the willies, but I wouldn't reccomend this game if you don't have patience for outdated gaming styles or outdated story telling.

Recomiendo ver un vídeo del gameplay mientras te "deleitas" con las escenas violentas ocurridas en el último tercio del juego. La trama del videojuego no tiene el más mínimo sentido (dicho por el creador) y fue una excusa para echar un pulso a la persecución sin descanso por erradicar la violencia en los diferentes medios. Como las aventuras gráficas estaban de moda a mediados de los noventa, pues se creó esta "obra" que buscaba tocar las narices a la censura(ridícula en muchos de los casos) que sufrían videojuegos, películas y demás obras.

¿Ni siquiera merece la pena como aventura gráfica? Tampoco. Puzzles sin sentido y rebuscados, sistema de combate pésimo que hace bloquearse al juego durante unos segundos, la mitad de las armas no valen ni para rascarse el culo, bugs destroza partidas que como no tengas un guardado antes del error la cagaste pero bien... encima todo lo "interesante" está por el final, ya que el comienzo es tan sumamente lento que 3 de cada 4 jugadores abandonarán el barco a los pocos minutos. Fue un rotundo fracaso en la época y ya resultaba pesado y difícil de digerir por aquel entonces, imaginad ahora.

Definiría a Harvester más o menos como dijo el autor y la prensa en la época. El juego de terror más estúpido y confuso jamás creado. Las conversaciones con los personajes son verdaderamente frustrantes y sin sentido, y la forma en que se desarrolla la trama resulta ser decepcionante y terriblemente aburrida. Lo poco positivo que tiene, que si sabes leer entre líneas (o buscar los 3 pies al gato, depende por donde se mire) la última planta de la logia, es una crítica brutal y perversa hacia la sociedad y la vida misma. Siento decirlo, pero es terrorificamente, muy acertada...

26336000.review:
SIn lugar a dudas, Harvester es el juego más raro y bizarro al que he jugado jamás. Es más, es el juego más raro y bizarro al que cualquiera podrá jugar jamás. La razón es simple: ya no se hacen juegos tan sumamente inadecuados en la industria del videojuego.  Durante el juego se tratan temas tan variados como el asesinato, la pederastria, la brutalidad infantil, y así un largo etcétera de situaciones politicamente muy incorrectas y, en ciertos momentos, de muy mal gusto.

Poco importa que creas que has jugado a cosas parecidas, donde la sangre habitaba por doquier y la psicopatía estaba a la orden del día. No sabrás qué significa la incorrección moral y ética en un juego hasta que no disfrutes de Harvester. Como he dicho, hoy es francamente complicado poder encontrarse algo parecido a lo que ofreció este título en 1996.

Esta aventura gráfica de estilo Full Motion Video (FMV) que tanto estaban de moda con la llegada del DVD a mediados de los 90 nos situa en un típico pueblecito americano de los años 50 donde nos despertamos en nuestra habitación después de sufrir una horrible pesadilla sin saber dónde estamos y qué hacemos en esa casa. Nuestros padres no parecen ser nuestros padres, y lo mismo pasa con el resto de la familia y habitantes del pueblo. Y para colmo vamos a casarnos en dos semanas con alguien a quien no conocemos de nada!!!

Este es el planteamiento inicial del juego, comenzar a deambular por Harvest para descubrir qué nos está pasando. El pueblo no puede ser más raro y bizarro. Gente realmente extraña puebla ese lugar, donde las situaciones más extrañas se ven como algo totalmente lógico y normal. En este sentido recuerda mucho a esas películas de serie B de extraterrestres, donde los humanos no son más que carcasas vacías controladas por poderes superiores. No van por ahí los tiros, sin embargo.

El juego como tal, aparte de su rarísimo argumento, muestra una jugabilidad al más puro estilo point & click. Recogemos objetos y los combinamo o usamos con el entorno. En este aspecto nada nuevo. Los puzles no son excesivamente complejos, pero tampoco hay excesivas pistas o indicios en algunos momentos, sobre todo al principio, provocando que el jugador pueda sentirse un poco perdido.

Por otro lado, el aspecto sonoro el juego es realmente bueno. Tienen una música que le viene como anillo al dedo y un doblaje en español de gran calidad, sobretodo si tenemos en cuenta que está realizado en 1996.

Todo lo comentado configura una aventura gráfica realmente única, incluso con su dosis arcade, donde lo que más brilla con luz propia es su argumento, el cual es realmente sosprendente. Para bien y para mal.

En definitiva, si te gustan las aventuras gráficas y quieres probar algo totalmente distinto que no te dejará indiferente, Harvester es realmente un juego que merece la pena. Sin lugar a dudas.

25989262.review:
At first glance, this game looks awful. It's easy to dismiss it as just another zany product of the failed FMV phase of video games, especially with the game proudly and shamelessly wearing its exploitation label like a medal. "The goriest game of all time!" It says, sometimes coupled with screenshots that appear to show more gore-for-the-sake-of-gore. This is just the most obvious basis one can use to write Harvester off, but if you're willing to venture beyond that, you'll find many more.

It's pretty meta, because Harvester throws the player off constantly. This in itself is one of the entire points of the game. The bizarre characters, the seemingly unclear satire on violence in video games, it's all there for a reason, and it took me several playthroughs to get the full meaning. The first time through it's just plain-old bizarre and enjoyable, though I recalled being intensely disappointed by the final act, especially the endings. Up to that point I had loved it in a purely "interactive B-movie" sense, but the game decided to throw even that away at its conclusion. Bundled with the atrocious combat system, it seemed like a wasted opportunity.

Except... Maybe not.

*Spoilers*

Here's the method to its madness: the main character of the game is not only Steve, but also you as a player. Steve is believable on his own, but he serves mostly as a stand-in for the audience. The goal is for Steve (you) to slowly become desensitized to violence over the course of the story. This is achieved first by amnesia, so this new environment you absorb shapes your worldview. Then you're pushed to do trivial tasks that quicky escalate in intensity and depravity (scratching a tucker to burning down one's livelihood). This is why Steve begins to act out-of-character, because by choosing to progress, you and him both are on the path to becoming a cold, detached serial killer.

Once you enter the lodge you actually begin to start killing. First with monsters, then to creatures that are more humanoid, then finally people. You target bad people, those viewed as "righteous", and ultimately those that are entirely innocent. By the time you've reached Stephanie, you've become a serial killer.

This is all an elaborate play on the claim that "video games make people serial killers", as parodied in the "bad" ending of the game. The over-the-top gore is there to eccentuate that, and to draw-in the kinds of people who are offended by it. Too bad it missed the peak of that controversy by two years (1996 vs. 1994), but with our current political climate it's become surprisingly relevant again.

The remarkably surreal "age-of-innocence" 50s atmosphere is a direct juxtaposition to all this, and it really, really works. Never have I played a game that gave me a more palpable sense of bleakness and entrapment. The peculiar soundtrack, hammy acting and unrealistic FMV only enhance it; the town of Harvest truly feels like a prison. And it's for good reason - the townspeople are weird and act like artificial caricatures because you're supposed to feel like an outsider, like the world is conspiring against you. By inflicting a sense of otherness it's supposed to make you (Steve) hostile against and distrusting of people in general.

The comparison to the works of David Lynch, Twin Peaks especially, would be the easiest to make. Besides maybe for "Bad Day on the Midway" there's no game more Lynchian that I've ever played, and (aside from Eraserhead) I don't even like Lynch. I believe this is a testament to how well Harvester stands on its own two feet.

But it's far from perfect. In terms of gameplay the puzzles are merely tolerable, and as mentioned the combat towards the end is inexcusably bad. You get accustomed to it eventually, but no doubt it should have been better-implemented. At least it serves its purpose for the narrative, unlike the game's dialogue choices, because...

It's a huge, gaping contradiction that the game's "better" ending even exists. The dialogue choices are essentially the player's conscience actively going against Steve's conditioning, but being offered an alternative ending after all that dulls the whole point of them as well as everything else the game built up. Perhaps if the player picked the more "morally-right" choice every time, and the "better" ending was the result, then it'd make a bit more sense. On top of being a lazy design choice, it's a totally inexplicable flaw.

Not to mention it's also a definite fault of the game that it requires this much unnecessary analysis to grasp the points I elaborated on above. Seeing as they're pretty much integral to understanding the game they should have been far more fleshed out, as they're only glossed-over on their surface level. But at the very least, they're still absolutely there, and they're fascinating.

Harvester had potential to be a prime example of artistic satire in video games, but it ended up instead being an often screwy and sometimes chilling journey into absurdity. As is, it's still excellently written, with an incredibly effective setting and oddly memorable characters. But beyond that are glimpses of what it further could have been, and while you have to look pretty hard to see them they should still be recognized for genuinely being there. I see this game get unfairly stigmatized all the time. People go for the easy targets (i.e. ham-fisted meat symbolism) and fail to examine the underlying bigger-picture. Huge applause for the effort made by the writer and director, Gilbert P. Austin. Because besides just being delightfully bizarre, the game actually has some legitimately compelling ideas.

25434577.review:
Harvester es una aventura grafica de la era donde el CD-ROM era relativamente nuevo y se aprovechaba para hacer juegos con FMVs (Full Motion Video) algunos juegos tenian escenas hechas en 3D pero el mercado entró en una era donde era popular incorporar actores grabando escenas para incorporarlas en un videojuego y hacerlo mas interactivo tratando de crear una experiencia mas cinematografica.

El juego tiene su fama por ser polemico tratando temas oscuros y escenas extremadamente graficas mostrando violencia, sangre o mejor conocido como Gore. El mismo muy al estilo de peliculas de antaño de ese estilo como Evil Dead, por lo mismo no es un juego para todo tipo de publico ya que mas de uno podrá salir ofendido o sorprendido con como el juego se desenvuelve lentamente en un festival de violencia y humor negro.

En el juego tomamos el rol de Steve un joven que despierta de pronto en Harvest un pequeño pueblo con no mas de 50 habitantes, sufre de amnesia y trata de buscar quien es y por que se encuentra en ese pueblo algo extraño. Conforme vas conociendo los habitantes del pequeño pueblo de Harvest podras darte cuenta de que hay algo que no esta bien y no es un lugar donde quisieras estar por mucho tiempo.

Todos esperan que te unas a un grupo especial localizados en el Lodge donde tu destino será definido, pero ¿Que realmente es lo que se supone que haces ahi? poco a poco conforme los dias pasan el protagonista se dará cuenta del por que de las cosas. Entre tantos personajes extraños y muy entablados en un cliche especifico de ciudadanos estadounidenses de los años 50s o 60s conoces a Stephanie la cual parece estar en la misma situación que el personaje principal, no solo eso, Stephanie es tu prometida y la boda esta por suceder pronto aunque ambos afirman no conocerse hasta el momento en que se conocen en el primer dia del juego.

Tratar mas sobre la trama del juego seria pasar la barrera de spoilers y arruinaria la sorpresa a posibles interesados en aventuras graficas de la epoca dorada del cdrom. Si algo de sangre, violencia, temas sexuales (no hay escenas con desnudos) y sátira sobre la violencia en los videojuegos y como esta afecta a los que interactuan con las mismas podria recomendar ampliamente jugar almenos una vez Harvester ya que podria considerarse una experiencia que vale la pena como algo extraño y unico en el mundo de los videojuegos.

Harvester utiliza DOSBOX para funcionar pero no causa grandes problemas con sistemas modernos, lo terminé sin muchos problemas en Windows 7, si deseas tomar screenshots y utilizar la interfase de steam mientras juegas asegurate de utilizar la segunda opción que te lanza el juego al ejecutarlo desde tu biblioteca de juegos.

Pros:
+ Una clasica experiencia de un juego de aventura point and click de los 90s.
+ El pequeño pueblo de Harvest esta lleno de amplia atencion y detalle en cada una de sus esquinas y habitantes.
+ Buenas voces y cuenta con doblaje en español, recomendaria jugarlo en ingles pero en caso de no saber el idioma la opción debe de estar disponible.
+ Lleno de humor negro, no se detiene o nada lo frena en expresar el mensaje que quiere dar al jugador.
+ Funciona sin problemas mediante DOSBOX reduciendo casi al 100% los posibles problemas con equipos modernos.

Contras:
- De la misma manera que no se restringe en dar su mensaje claramente puede que sea mucho para algunas personas que sean sensibles a muestras extremas de violencia.
- Trata temas que pueden ser polemicos para mas de uno como violencia, suicidio, canibalismo, vouyerismo, violencia a menores, crimen, vandalismo entre otras cosas perturbadoras no aptas para menores o personas que se puedan ofender facilmente con algo como esto.
- Al ser un juego de aventura clasico puede ser algo criptico y requiere mucha prueba y error para progresar en la historia pero hay varias guias disponibles para estos casos.
- De igual manera al ser un juego de los 90s su control puede ser algo complicado en algunos casos sobretodo en la parte final del juego donde se convierte en algo mas de acción donde el personaje principal tiene que defenderse de enemigos, curarse y demas. Altamente recomendable guardar tu partida constantemente en diferentes slots.

Calificación: 7 de 10.

Recomendado para fans de los juegos de aventura grafica que buscan algo diferente y perturbador.

TLDR: Only recommended for hardcore old-school PnC Adventure Games or gore fans.

I love adventures...been playing them for a solid 25 years. I remember when this game came out and I really wanted to get it...but alas the store (nor my mom) would let me get it. Eventually after all the years, I found a boxed copy and found it on Steam.

+ First off, I love the obscure, ultra-violent weird take on normally a docile genre of games.  This game was well beyond anything in the 90s.
+ The acting is awesomely bad (to me this was a plus.)
+ There is definitely a great dose of dark comedy.
+ The message is an obvious but strong one.  I do think it serves a very important part of gaming history because of this...especially when you get to the endgame.
+ This game works really well as a horror game.  The scenes and FMV shots can be very gruesome, which are generally very well done for the time.

24992771.review:
Ah, Harvester, it's a classic full motion video (FMV) point-and-click game that has been both praised and scorned over the years. When it originally came out in 1996, many critics said that the game felt dated due to its delayed release, but these days gamers can't seem to get enough of this gore-soaked B-Grade title; save for the prudes who don't enjoy cheesy horror like Evil Dead, Basket Case, or even Silent Night, Deadly Night. 

During the game, you play as an 18 year old guy named Steve Mason; trust me, you were always such a kidder, Steve. It turns out that he has severe amnesia, to the point that he doesn't even remember that he's engaged and set to be wed to a woman named Stephanie in three weeks time. No one in the town of Harvest believes that he has amnesia, which frustrates him to no end. During the time that you will spend in the small town of Harvest, population 51, you will meed a variety of wildly eccentric and somewhat wacky characters, all who have their own personality quirks; a deputy who is obsessed with jerking off to nudie mags, Stephanie's father who is off his rocker about meat, a crazy school teacher who thinks that the best way to discipline her students is by beating them with a baseball bat, gay firemen... the list just goes on and on.

Well, it turns out that Stephanie has just as severe of a case of amnesia that Steve does. The goal of the game comes down to getting in to this mysterious, secret organization known as The Order of the Harvest Moon, whose headquarters are located at the Lodge. Steve needs to join them prior to the Harvest Annual Blood Drive Donation at the end of the week, which is mandatory... and perhaps deadly. The gameplay is separated in to days, and as such you will play through a total of six days (some with night events) and three levels of the Lodge. The entire game, if you're using a guide, will take around 7-8 hours to complete; if you're not using a guide, it could take you upwards to 20 hours to figure out the complex puzzles and how to initiate the game moving from one day to the next.

Harvest is a fairly large town for having such a small population, it has 18 locations to explore; although some of them you will only end up visiting once or twice. There are just as many characters to interact and converse with, as well as to potentially murder. That's right, Harvester also features a fighting mechanic; left clicking lets you examine, pick up, and use objects, while right clicking lets you attack. You will find a large amount of weapons to use during the course of your playthrough, all which can be individually equipped via the inventory screen. Not only are you able to kill people, but once you reach the later Lodge levels, there are monsters that you will have to take out as well.

Surprisingly, this title has aged incredibly well in both looks and functionality. The abundant FMVs are riddled with gore, cheesy dialogue, and bad acting; even though they're low quality and slightly pixelated, they're still incredibly enjoyable to watch time and time again. It's even worth it to go out of your way to explore all of the different ways that Steve can die, and to interact with all of the characters as many times as possible to view all of the cutscenes. Talking with people in the town of Harvest will show "key words" that you can select that act as topics for discussion, though some disappear after speaking about another subject you can type in any keywords that were available; this is one retro game where keeping a pen and paper handy is actually still useful.

I could go on singing praises about Harvester all day, but sadly the Steam version has a few kinks that will most likely never be worked out. For some people, the game crashes often; this did not happen to me. For a lot of people, the FMV cutscenes, which are arguably the best part of the game, will refuse to play; this actually did happen to me, and you do miss out not on just a lot of the fun stuff, but a lot of the story as well. There's only one known fix for the latter issue, and that's to lower the frame cycles in DOSBox to 8000. Doing so makes the gameplay infuriatingly choppy and sluggish, fortunately most of the FMVs are located on the sixth day, and only sporadically throughout the rest of the game.

Even with the problems that weigh this port down, Harvester is an amazingly fun, low-budget horror title that's seething with blood, gore, intestines, crude phallic jokes, bad acting, cheesy dialogue, and hilarious FMV cutscenes. Some of the more memorable moments for me were when the deputy was caught jerking off, and finding the children eating their mother; not to mention the countless sessions of dialogue that will stick with you, such as the meat obsessed father of the bride. If you're a fan of old B-Grade movies like the ones I listed in the introductory paragraph, or if you played and enjoyed games such as Sanitarium, Phantasmagoria, and I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream, then you will absolutely dig Harvester. However, for a dollar more you can purchase it on GOG and avoid any potential issues that the Steam version has.

To its credit, I was so interested on what the hell was going on and where the story would take me that I watched a playthrough on Youtube.  It is a very interesting idea and was actually some decent satire of the early censorship and view towards violent video games back in the 90's.
Spoilers:
[spoiler]
Basically, the game is a "Harvester" to find and train the best murderers.  Your character has a crucial choice to make at the end that decides if you have the cold ability to murder without remorse, and by extension, the player themselves.  I found this to be a great tongue-in-cheek jab at what the early violence censoring/fearmongering committees believed (and may still believe) about violent TV/Video games/movies.

23626595.review:
The story surrounding Harvester and the concepts of Harvester are actually surprisingly interesting. It's a game that suffered a lot from being in a transitional period for computer hardware and software, and the manufactured controversy angle it went for completely fell flat on its face as Harvester missed its initial release date by two years.

Harvester does a lot of things other games get credit for but all the way back in 1996 (technically as early as '94 if you cut the developer some slack). While it's under developed puzzles and ludicrous content (the gay firehouse and ability to kill children strike me as two elements definitely unlikely to fly in modern times) make it hard to recommend for gameplay purposes, and the end 'boss rush'-sequence borders on unfair, this game does three things well: metafictional commentary, ludonarrative harmonium, and actually interesting content (the aforementioned boss rush has one fmv sequence that is genuinely disturbing and I really dug that). 

This game taunts players and crafts a self aware and self reflexive narrative that is enjoyable for its timeliness. This preceeds many great games that experiment with the meta, such as Metal Gear Solid and Undertale for two easy examples. It's also a lovely time capsule in how to approach these elements and how public thinking on video games was truly absurd at one point. 

It is also a game that possess very poor gameplay. It wasn't good when it came out and it isn't interesting in retrospect. That said, many of the gameplay choices are fascinating "in concept", but more importantly, and especially with the game's central twist in mind, many of the design choices make sense within the context of the game world. This doesn't make it fun to play as the combat is bad and the puzzles are lazy, but in more capable hands some of it's more noble failures could have been executed interestingly.

Lastly, this is a game that is full of schlock and absolute trashiness. My brother and I actually played through this whole ordeal together, and for large parts it fails to be horrifying and it fails to be shocking. Even at time of release, much of its most disturbing content was at best in poor taste and at worst completely uninteresting. That said, this gives is a b-movie kind of charm. Scratch that. It gives it a z-movie kind of charm. The terrible fmvs are enjoyable kitschy, but on the rare occasion this games content actually works in its intended fashion (off the top of my head, the peeping tom next door dad is a sequence that is gross but deservedly so, and the trials of the lodge have a few moments of actually dark content) by George it actually works. And you almost want to root for the game for that.

Basically, if you have a Sunday to kill, maybe a few beers, this is a game worth playing for that kind of "are you kidding me, this is so stupid" kind of entertainment. I'm solidly recommending it because let's plays exist and the game also goes on sale frequently. Plus, you can expedite many of its worst elements via cheat codes.

23351796.review:
I'm a longtime fan of FMV point & click adventure games, so I'll always be very lenient when judging these games. But Harvester just doesn't cut it. To review an adventure game, we need to talk about the setting and the story a bit, so the following may contain small spoilers, but don't worry: real spoilers will be hidden like so [spoiler]yup, like this[/spoiler].

[u]The story[/u]

You play Steve, who wakes up in the town of Harvest with amnesia. He doesn't remember anything or anyone, but everyone seems to know him and everyone seems to know he has amnesia before he tells them ("they heard about it"). On top of that, everyone looks bizarre and everyone acts completely psycho. Everyone except Stephanie, who's supposed to be Steve's fiancee, but they both don't remember anything. You see, Stephanie has amnesia just like Steve. Steve will go explore the town to find out what's going on.

At first, it's fun to explore the town and talk to the people, who are all complete nutjobs. But soon, the behavior of the main characters becomes outright unbelievable and you won't care much what they have to say anymore, you will just keep playing because you're curious to know what is going on and what type of creatures these so-called townspeople are. To discover that, you need to gain access to 'the lodge'. 

[u]The gameplay[/u]

Gameplay is classic point and click. Find items, combine them in your inventory and use them on things or people. There are a few points in the game where I had to look up a walkthrough. When I read the solution I never had the feeling it was completely impossible to guess, but it would sometimes have taken me hours to come up with it myself. 

Once you enter the lodge, the gameplay changes drastically. Fighting becomes a large part of the game. Now in my opinion, an adventure game shouldn't become a fighting game all of a sudden, especially when it has a combat system that's just awful. And the most infuriating part is [spoiler]that the last part of the game is just one fight after another. No more story or anything, just about a dozen or so fights. It feels like a bad Mortal Kombat or Streetfighter game. And because healing items are scarce, you will need to reload almost every time you get hit or you won't make it to the end.[/spoiler]

But you persist, because you're almost at the end of the game and you haven't even received the smallest bit of information about what the hell is going on. And then, the final cutscene explains the plot, and it's the biggest anticlimax in an adventure game ever. [spoiler]It turns out none of it was real. Everything from the first second of the game up to the end was just a virtual reality, an illusion. This made me yawn in anger. A long time ago, a tv series called Dallas pulled this off and really pissed off the fans by stating the whole previous season was just a dream. More recently, the tv series Lost pretty much did the same at the end of their final season. Well, here you play an adventure game wondering what the explanation is for all the weird things that happen and for the weird behaviour of the people, and the explanation is: "It didn't really happen. Roll the credits!" Bah![/spoiler]

[u]Conclusion[/u]

Nah, I don't recommend Harvester. The first part is somewhat fun, but the second part isn't and the ending just makes you want to shout cursewords at your screen. If you're looking for a good FMV, I recommend Gabriel Knight 2. Phantasmagoria isn't bad either. I even enjoyed Phantasmagoria 2 more than I did Harvester, and people who played both these games will know that's a bold statement ;-)

Zalety:

+ enigmatyczny i naprawdę niezwykle porąbany klimat ;)
+ czarne poczucie humoru i zabawne, dobrze napisane dialogi 
+ udana satyra na amerykańską popkulturę lat 50. i 80. w USA 
+ dziwaczne, niesamowicie pokręcone postaci (matka - żona ze Stepford, seksowna nastoletnia Stephanie z lat 80. amerykański sierżant tropiący komunistyczne spiski jak generał Ripper z kubrickowskiego Dr. Strangelove, zastępca szeryfa oglądający pornole w kiblu, strażnik loży przypominajacy Sitha ze Star Wars skrzyżowanego ze średniowiecznym mnichem itd.)
+ seks, przemoc i dużo krwi... a mocne sceny trafiają nas z zaskoczenia...
+ gra ma bardzo mocne sceny (według mnie najmocniejsza scena to ta w Świątyni Matczynej Miłości z matką i trójką jej dzieci - Ci co grali wiedzą o czym mowa ;)
+ wiele smakowitych scen - zwłaszcza z seksowną blondi o imieniu Stephanie ;)
+ można wyłączyć w menu efekty gore (dla co bardziej wrażliwych graczy)
+ niepokojąca muzyka w klimacie Silent Hilla (SH widocznie inspirował się muzą z Harvestera) 
+ technika FMV nadaje charakter grze (prawdziwi aktorzy wklejeni w grę) 
+ interesujące lokalizacje
+ w grze są wbudowane kody z czitami (bardzo pomagają w niektórych irytujących momentach)
+ Harvester ma 2 zakończenia do wyboru (oba bardzo dobre i zaskakujące)
+ przemyślana koncepcja fabularna - dopiero na końcu odkrywamy prawdę, o co tak naprawdę chodzi w tym Harvesterze ;)
+ grafika o dziwo dobrze się trzyma jak na 20 lat na karku

Wady: 

- kompletnie nietrafiony pomysł z walką w drugiej części gry 
- sterowanie w grze jest mało intuicyjne
- rozdzielczość nie jest zbyt wysoka i czasami jest problem z dostrzeżeniem przedmiotów 
- gra nie działa na każdej karcie graficznej (u mnie działa na integrze Intela, a na Nvidii nie)
- czasami można się zaciąć - polecam przechodzenie z poradnikiem
- w grze pozostały ekrany z prośbą o włożenie kolejnego CD do stacji dysków (zastąpione komendą CTRL+ F4+ LPM) :)
- przydałby się remaster HD tej gry

Podsumowanie:

Harvester to być może  najbardziej kontrowersyjna gra w historii, nie bez przyczny nazywana przez niektórych graczy kultową. Chociaż niepozbawiona wad technicznych, to jednak gra, w której trudno się nie zakochać. Harvestera polecam wszystkim, którzy cenią gry oryginalne, dziwaczne kimaty, tropienie popkulturowych nawiązań, a przemoc i seks im niestraszne. :) Jeżeli lubisz postmodernistyczne filmy Lyncha, Tarantino czy Rodrigueza na pewno pokochasz też Harvestera. Komu tę grę odradzam? Po pierwsze młodszym graczom, bo to nie jest gra dla nich. Po drugie odradzam ludziom bardzo wrażliwym na mocne sceny, krew i przemoc. Po trzecie, odradzam graczom bez elementarnego poczucia humoru. Zwłaszcza czarnego. ;)

Rady: 

1. Polecam podchodzić do tej gry z dystansem - jeżeli coś wydaje się Wam kiczowate to tylko dlatego, że twórcy świadpmie chcieli uzyskać taki efekt.
2. Harvester to gra, którą nie jest dla dzieci. Chociaż przemoc jest tutaj ujęta w nawias i podana z czarnym poczuciem humoru, to gra przeznaczona jest jednak dla graczy od 18 lat.  
3. Macie twardy żołądek? Jeżeli nie, to nie jedzcie kolacji grając w tę grę. ;)
4. Kobiety w ciąży i matki - wątpię, by któraś z Was trafiła na tę grę, ale jeżeli to czytacie - nawet nie próbujcie odpalać Harvestera. Dla Waszego własnego dobra... ;)

22733342.review:
I started playing the game without watching any walkthroughs, or anything.  I was never able to even get to the lodge.  How could this be?  I was stuck.  I had to go look for a walkthrough.  I realized the first problem.  I didn't pick up the pen and quarter from the drawer.  Of course, I should have been looking around my room, and opened the drawer.  Well, I did.  I clicked on the bookshelf, and I only got a description and I clicked on the closet next to my bed, and I only got a description.  I assumed that everything that can be examined would only be examined.  To prove my (incorrect) point even more, I tried to open the oven and cabinet in the kitchen.  None were able to be opened.

So, how could I differentiate between stuff that can be opened, and stuff that can't?  Well, there isn't any way.  I can’t even have my mouse over the drawer to know weather it can be opened.  I always get the “examine” cursor, so I would have to click on everything that has the examine cursor.

The same thing goes for items, but there aren’t that many items that are able to be picked up, so it’s not that bad.

It's not that the game is too hard, but if I have to click on every possible thing that can be opened (or look at a walkthrough), it just becomes tedious.

There could be a way to make it possible to know weather something can be opened after being examined, or if it would just be able to be examined.  A glow could be possible.

It does take a little bit of realism out if there is a way to know weather something opened or not.  It is needed to examine everything to know weather there is something important in it.  Then everything that can (in real life) be opened should show the contents, but since that would take too much time to program, and it would have nothing to do with the game itself, it would be good to only let things that are needed for the game to be able to open.  Since it takes a little bit of realism out, it would be a good idea to go a little bit further and have a way to know weather something can be opened or not just by looking.

The game has good graphics for it's time, and even though it was from 1995, it can still be ran with modern computers.  The game starts of slow, but gets gory fast.  I would recommend this because someone looking at this game would want something gory.  If I would review this game for the average person, I would not recommend it.

This game is great, but it's not for everyone.  If you want an interesting storyline, and is very gory, this is right for you.

Harvester is a crazy game, a sick game, a bloody game and sometimes a disgusting game. It's a gorefest.
It's quite a few years old but it's still an awesome game.
Put the old newspapers out every morning... if you don't the paperboy will shoot you. If you think it's a good idea to kill the paperboy first, be fast, otherwise you will die first :D
Prepare for kids feasting on their mother, knife-wielding lunatics, teachers hitting students with baseball bats and a lot more. And prepare for a sick and twisted ending, with the ultimate choice.
The game consists of lots of FMV scenes, the rest is point and click.

+ dark humor
+ darker humor
+ lots of wtf moments

Cons:

- sometimes cheap special effects (baby / spider)

Info:

Final words:
Get it. Just get it. It's worth it. Watch the clip and the pictures and if you can accept to play a 20 year old game, buy it today, or yesterday!
Definitely an experience you will never forget!
Oh and save all the time, since many decisions can get you insta-killed :D
Example: Now that's a nice hooker, let's say yes -> you will die! lmao!
