21240399.review:
A fatbellied lard-neck sheriff rips open a prison cell. We see his intense face accentuated by his many chins. He is glaring at a perverted old lawman whacking it to a porno magazine. He grabs the magazine, rolls it up and starts hitting him with it.

15/10

---------------------------------------------------------

Anyway, this is an extremely strange retro horror/adventure game with a KILLER( ba dum tsss) sense of humour. You walk around different areas looking like a character from Mortal Kombat and you can access the map at any time to travel to different parts of a small, weird town.

This is one of those old games where figuring out what you are supposed to do is next to impossible and a walkthrough(at least, for me anyway) is almost mandatory to beat the game.

You play as a young man of nonspecific age who wakes up not knowing what the hell is going on. All around town the people are really creepy and weird. There's a military guy who has no legs or groin who guards a nuclear missle base sitting in town, there's a house with some old wasp lady(who doesn't factor into the game's story at all. you don't even have to go to her house to complete the game), there's a butcher shop with blood everywhere and dead cats all over the place and there's a giant druid-looking building called "The Lodge".

You find out that you're supposed to try and become a member of The Lodge by the end of the week and to do so you have to complete tasks for the really cool guy who runs it. A guy, who talks with his mind in an awesome voice. 

I don't think I would have been able to figure out what to do honestly but basically in completing the tasks you will talk to all kinds of people and the story is littered with creativity and incredibly dark campy humor. In this story you will see many cutscenes with the bad actors being hilarious in front of crappily animated early-3D backgrounds and it's a wonderful sight to behold. It seems as if the developers thought of everything as there are so many secrets to be found through dialogues and doing things in certain orders that triggers funny responses and, in some cases, exclusive death cutscenes. Any time you die it will trigger a cutscene of the main hero being brutally murdered in whatever manner you managed to die in the game.

I think that if you like the early Peter Jackson films like Bad Taste or Dead Alive(known as Brain Dead in some countries) then you should really consider giving Harvester a play and maybe even look at walkthrough to see what this game has to offer. Once you complete all of the tasks and get into the lodge finally you have to complete the "trials" of becoming a lodgemember and it's really cool to see what lies inside. It's a huge building with so much personality and creativity around every corner and once you get through it you have access to an awesome twist that explains what is going on and a choice between two solid endings.

-------------------------------------------------

After hearing things about this game I always thought that it would be worth a look and boy, was I right. Now this game probably isn't for anyone, as people seem more sensitive these days(no offense) but the non-pc humor happened to be right up my alley. 

I do feel bad for the original makers of Harvester as, after they had completed the game it took them a year or two to finish the programming and by that time the it was already outdated as technology was rapidly improving around the time this game came to fruition and the game didn't sell very well.

Nightdive Studios made the game accessible without using DOS and polished up a bit for easy use and I really love them for redoing a bunch of retro games and selling them on Steam. They did System Shock 1 and 2, Turok, Shadow Man and on top of that they're doing their own modern sequel or remake of System Shock!

While I do wish the original creators of Harvester could be getting more money for their game on Steam(I am almost positive they are not but correct me if I am wrong) I am definetely happy to give my money to the great Nightdive Studios.

From the darkest heart of 1990's gaming comes one of the most unabashedly fuck-ed up games FMV technology could create.  The characters and situations are so terminally freaking weird that I honestly felt like I was high for the first hour of the story.  As the game continues it progresses from merely strange through to disturbing and finally ending on outright horror.  By the end, blood and gore are omnipresent, and it all becomes so over the top it's laughable while still being gross.  

Unfortunately that wonderfully odd ambiance is broken due to two flaws in the game.  Some of the puzzles tend to be on the more obscure side, as in nearly impossible to figure out unless you have a walk-through guide.  Fortunately, steam provides one.  Also, you'll want to create numerous separate save files at various points throughout the game, since you *can* get locked into situations were you may have neglected to pick up an item which was critical to completing the game, but it's impossible to backtrack to retrieve it.  However, I only found this to happen in one area late in the game.  

Final verdict:  if you can work around the technical flaws and enjoy weird atmosphere and offensive humor with campy acting, give this a try.

19804220.review:
I play point-and-click adventures for a very long time, but still, somehow, I missed this game when it was released back in the 1996. So I have decided to try it now. I thought that it would be good adventure with quite abstract story, but I was wrong. Yes, the "story" is really abstract. But the game is not good at all. I don't care too much about obsolete graphic, clunky controls, but I care about gameplay in general.
This game can be completed without walkthroughs/hints only if you have at least some skill in telepathy, because gameplay here consists only of searching items that you will need in future. And you rarely know what developers want from you right now. For instance:  [spoiler] Day 5, we need to commit arson in the Diner. So, what options do we have: 1) We have the man, that commited arsons in the past. Maybe we need to speak to him. No! 2) Maybe we need to lure the Diner owner outside first. No! 3) OK, maybe we try to talk to the man that feels lust for the Diner owner. No! ... khm, what must we do then? We must go to the church and randomly click on the coffin, suddenly there we see a deceased man. But we have been here before and coffin was empty. OK. We must take a photograph of the deceased and exchange it for glue. End of Day 5.[/spoiler] And the whole game consists of similar "puzzles" - click every screen over and over again until you'll suddenly find something new. 18886718.review:
So I bought this game recently cause it was on sale, and also because I watched a playthrough of it a long time ago. It tells the intriguing story of a young man named Steve, who finds himself in the mysterious town "Harvest" after waking up with amnesia. The town is populated with a couple dozen people, most vastly differing from one another, producing a nice cast of memorable and unique characters. Steve, the main character, is personally my favourite. I love his dialogue and I found myself connecting to him and his situation -- something that doesn't usually happen for me.  

Throughout the game you will uncover the secrets of Harvest, most opening up more questions than answers. This adds to the mystery of the town, producing a nice spooky vibe which fits it's horror genre. While playing I found myself simultaneously laughing, crying, and cringing; it's the perfect combination of humour and disgust. You can't help but feel pity for Steve, who like you has no idea what's going on or why he's there. 

A warning to anyone squeamish: This game is not for the lighthearted. Though the graphics may be older, some of the cutscenes are surprisingly brutal, and without going into too much detail, very gory. There's no real jumpscares though, which is nice. Just be wary that at any second a cutscene could come out of nowhere. There's child/baby death in this game too, which may (understandly) bother some people. In general, the farther you progress the more gory it gets. So if you are faint of heart, I advise you not to play this game.

PROS:
-Great story with somewhat satisfying conclusions
-Amazing characters
-Not afraid of it's audience
-Decent voice acting
-Great cutscenes
-Graphics aren't bad for an older game
-Steve

CONS:
-Fighting is lackluster
-Some may find endings unsatisfactory
-Gets pretty weird (it's for you to decide if this is a good or a bad thing)
-Dead babies, mutilated children, wounded cats, blah blah blah
-Too many wasps
-Steve is a kidder

All in all, I highly recommend this game to people who enjoy classic horrors with unique charm and a weird, crazy plot. If you're looking for a game that'll make you question what the f**k is going on, then this game is for you. If older graphics really bother you then they may be a problem, but personally they were good enough to make me genuinely scared at some points (which is good enough for me). Basically, just buy this game. I promise you you won't find another one like it.

17837761.review:
A 90s cult classic with a lot of splatter that could have been an excellent horror b-movie. Beautiful and gory in all it's campy glory. Reminiscent of Phantasmagoria, in a more...Evil Dead kind of way. 

Featuring delightfully absurd dialogues that are sometimes unexpectedly insightful, a batshit crazy ending and buckets of black, morbid humor. If you have even the slightest taste for horror you should definitelly check this old gem.

I love old games like this one. At the time the different genres of gaming weren't so clear-cut as they are today. Not having the imperative to be separated in perfect little boxes in order to identify a game as "adventure", "action" etc, resulted in games like Harvester. A game with heavy adventure elements, timed events, combats, different weapons you can actually aim and use, ammo to manage and of course, many deaths. 

There is a weird exhilarating sense of freedom in that lack of genre labeling in gameplay. You can't follow the patterns modern adventure games use, so even simple things may have an unexpected aspect to them. This kind of freedom in a game's design makes it more interesting -and of course, at times, harder to beat.*

Unfortunately Harvester also carries with it the sexist tropes of the era, so if you can't stomach good old sexism, a touch of homophobia, gratuitous sex scenes, ladies in lingerie and violence against women then you should probably choose another game. I was able to enjoy it despite of this, but I can't say that this will be the case for everyone.


*But, thankfully,  in case you get stuck, it has one of the most beloved "features" of old games: cheat codes. N00b players everywhere, REJOICE!

Harvester is an old point and click adventure game, though some sections are timed and require quick thinking under pressure. The game is a satire with a very 'twin peaks' feel. The satire comes in the form of the fact that it was deliberately made for shock value and to piss off moral crusaders. The puzzles are fun, but as all adventure games from the era had, there are a few nonsensical solutions and pixel hunts. 
Pros:
-Great humor and a real sense of self awareness
-Interesting ending(s)
-"Quality time" with the principal
-Cannibals
-Commies
-Top of the line FMV
-Pixels
-Steve, the kidder
Cons:
-Abrupt adjustment to combat in last part
-Endings might not be very satisfying
-Nonsensical puzzles (why would you use the dolly there?)

Overall, I recommend this game. One might want a guide handy for the really bad puzzles, but the story and humor are enjoyable enough to drive the game despite clunky gameplay mechanics.

17067552.review:
It's an interesting concept to give any freedom to player in point'n'click games, it's worth checking out as there are not that many games like that [even though that freedom is usually very limited or glitched beyond helping]. The main pro of this game would definitely be it's atmosphere, a wicked version of 50s USA created in the 90s with cheesy dialogues and acting. You may find yourself pushing forward just because you want to discover all the unreal wonders of Harvest.

Unfortunately the game is not remastered or anything, it's emulated through DOSbox with most of the inconveniences of the initial release, very low resolution, cutscenes problems, infamous twitchy and not-fun-at-all combat. 
Another huge problem would be second part of the game, it revolves around combat and is more linear, like most of the other point'n'clicks. 
What's more about that part is mandatory item hunting, as the game does not allow the slightest backtracking then, which means that if you haven't picked up a crucial puzzle piece and saved on only one slot.....well, have fun starting from monday.

I picked it up knowing what it is, and for those who don't, but are curious- some guides/walkthroughs and multiple saves may make the game playable instead of tedious. 
I like some of the more original and funny games like this one, but then again- I always was a kidder.

"You always were a kidder, Steve!"

Эта игра мало известна даже в родной стране, что уж там Европа с Россией... Даже пиратские издатели до недавнего времени её не переводили. Тем не менее, игра пользуется популярностью в узких кругах любителей поиграть в такие игры, как GTA, POSTAL, Manhunt, Carmageddon и т.д.

Сюжет неплох. Главный герой, 18-летний Steve Mason, просыпается с амнезией в 1953 году в городе Harvest. Далее он знакомится с жителями города и получает от них задания. Всё бы хорошо, но я ведь уже говорил, что игра похожа на POSTAL?

Графика выполнена в стиле Motion Capture + видеовставки, чем напоминает Resident Evil. Не сказать, что это её сильная сторона.

Жанр игры: квест-приключение, point-n-click. Причём очень сложная. Безусловно, в плюс. Каждый проигрыш анимирован кат-сценой; по сути почти каждое действие анимировано кат-сценами. Не знаю, плюс или минус.

В общем, долго думал, и поставил чуть выше среднего из-за оригинальности игры.

А купив её по скидке, повысил оценку, поиграв несколько часов, и дошёл до пятницы до последнего задания. Квесты интересные (но местами очень отвратительные; спойлерить не буду), можно проходить по-хорошему (правильному), а можно посмотреть все плохие концовки. Также имеется много вульгарного, чёрного, неполиткорректного, игрового и тому подобного юмора, схожего с POSTAL, а то и переплёвывающего последний.

Совет: никого не убивайте и не причиняйте другим вреда! После покидания локации вы попадёте в полицию, а затем - прямиком на электрический стул, где вас будут ждать мама, шериф и загадочный Sergeant-in-Arms.

Концовки приятно удивят внезапным поворотом сюжета.

15466037.review:
Harvester is a classic point and click adventure game originally released in the mid 90s. upon purchase on steam, It comes with a journal article basically stating stuff about violence in video games. So you can expect an epicly gorey and surreal adventure. You'll want to try and explore every area of the game and you'll be surprised or shocked by some of the stuff you'll see.

If you remember the classic point and click adventure games, then you'd already know the fundamentals of playing this game. Click on things, Pick up items, Heavy dialog from various NPCs, Work out cryptic puzzles, Think about using an FAQ. All those natrual moments of point and click adventures will come to you. So if that thrills you, This is a title to pick up. If you need an extra push on the decision... here's the story.

The beauty of this game is basically waking up not knowing a single thing. You dont know where you are, who you are, or what you are meant to do. and after briefly talking to various people in the town, You find out you have amnesia. As you discover parts about yourself, you also learn the town you are in is not exactly like other towns. You have your average buildings like Schools, Police station, General store but the largest building in the centre of the town is The Lodge. No one in town knows whats inside but you'll need to gain access to it. If you manage to succeed, You might be lucky to actually understand what the whole story of this game is.

As for the violence and gore? Well there's definately a lot of that. There was several settings and scenarios that may upset some people and if I could admit, there was one particular scene I came across which even I was shocked by. The FMV movies have some porno-intro style acting but it gives the game a unique touch. 

It might feel dated now, but the story and the enviroment you are traveling through. It feels like a surreal bad dream and for some reason, when things are so creepy or unusual we cant help but be curious to get more. So I'd say if you can get this game, Grab it.

15463804.review: Harvester is a point and click horror/adventure game from the 90s.  What sets it apart from other games in its genre is how insane it is.  This game has things in it that would not stand a chance at making it into releases today.  Sure, blood and gore are pretty common today, but when it involves children, it's just completely taboo now.  Not surprisingly, Harvester has a pretty decent sized cult following.  It was hit hard when it was released by negative criticism for its gameplay but mostly for its content.  It definitely broke no ground with its gameplay and its content is pretty shocking.  I found the tone of the game to be just perfect.  It is just creepy beyond reason.  Kind of like a cheesy horror flick or something. 15267414.review:
"You always were a kidder Steve...."


A cult classic point and click adventure game from 1996 that managed to spark quite a bit of controversy at the time of its release due to its graphical violence and generally messed up and twisted themes . You play as a character called Steve who wakes up in town called Harvest somewhere in the 50's. He doesn't remember why or how he got there, and he can't recognize his not-so-idyllic family. Pretty soon he starts to realize that things are very, very wrong in this small town. And the only one besides Steve who realizes this, is his soon-to-be fiance who lives next door. The true nature Harvest will unveil as you progress through the game.

Gameplay is exactly like you would expect from any point and click adventure game from the 90's. You walk through different parts of the town gathering stuff and trying to figure out whats going on while talking to all the peculiar characters in the town. The game has its share of some flawed and obscure puzzles. The game also has some extremely clunky combat elements, but you won't be needing combat till much later in the game, so it doesn't really matter. 
You can also kill every character in this game if you want to, but you'll be sent to the electric chair if theres any witnesses around.

Graphics are pretty abysmal by todays standards, but I think it just brings more charm into this game. Not to mention all the greenscreen cutscenes which were so hilariously bad that they were funny as hell.

Overall, this game is a rare gem and should be played by anyone who enjoys old-school adventure games and/or downright fucked up games.

14728384.review:
Harvester is a sometimes uncomfortable mix of oddly done social commentary, and a collection of sometimes awful ironic funny moments delievered in the style of an odd D-List FMV game.

You play as Steve, the Plaid shirt wearing kidder of Harvester. You wonder around Harvester, trying to remember what's what as you suffer from amnesia all of a sudden. Harvester is from the odd age of PC games, or at least right at the end of it. The game is a point 'n' click, complete with odd plots, pixel hunting, and sometimes hilariously woeful animations, visualisations and 'great' voice acting. The game tries to mix things up near the end, with very mixed results, with some sections coming off as boring or weak compared to the rest of the game.

The quirk, is that nothing is ordinary. People are obsessed with anything, be it corpses, meat, wasps, or whatever else. FMV cutscenes tell the story hilariously. As mentioned before, the voice acting and ridiculous writing that would ruin any other game gives Harvester an excellent personality. Be it staring at Spinal Cords and thinking about pie, or be it becoming somewhat genuinely disturbing, Harvester's plot is memorable because of its plot is its greatest quirk.

Visually, it’s an FMV game, and you can tell by looking at it that it's an FMV. The characters feature quite a bit of animation considering this. Unfortunately, dialogue is not animated, but it is fully voiced by Harvester's all-star cast, which although all sound really odd, perfectly portray the screwed up world that Steve inhabits. The environments are extremely weird, and the cutscenes featuring full-motion video are extremely strange.

The soundtrack is very varied, featuring a variety of different music. Although it sometimes seems unsuitable, once again because of the weirdness this game strives in, I can't tell if this is intentional, or if it’s just really shoddy design.

Overall, there isn't much you can say about Harvester. Harvester is just a bloody weird game, and because Harvester is so weird, I have to recommend this to as many people as possible. The game is just weird, and deserves some attention now, being a breath of fresh air in the modern day of serious, competitive gaming. Although the game gets weaker near the end, there is plenty of meat here to keep you entertained, despite its stupidity.

14387250.review:
If you like point and click games and can handle adult humor, some disturbing content and a lot of gore, then I would definetly recommend this game. I enjoyed it a lot more than I thought I was going to.

The game took me 18 hours to complete, but that is because while playing I went back in saves to explored every possible outcome of each situation and to hear all the dialogue possible in each conversation depending on the questions I asked or answers I gave. If you rush through the game you can probably beat it in half that time.


A few technical tips if you do pick up this game.

Save often, especially later in the game. The game allows you to save 25 times before having to overwrite old saves. This is for 2 reasons. One, there are a lot of situations where there are different outcomes depending on what you say or do and you may want a recent save point to try out all the options without having to go back to an old save and repeat a bunch of stuff. Two, this game is run through DosBox and it has problems with skipping some of the cutscenes.

In the DosBox settings (steamapps\common\Harvester\dosbox_windows\dosbox_harvester.conf) you will want to set a certain cycle number to play at and then use the cycle down and up shortcuts (ctrl F11 & F12) while in game when you get to a cutscene that was skipped. I used these settings, but you may need to adjust them a little for your computer: cycles=28000, cycleup=20000, cycledown=20000, aspect=true. When a cutscene is skipped, load the previous save (beginning of that conversation if you are saving a lot), press F11 to drop the cycles down to allow the cutscene to play and then press F12 to bring them back up so the game plays faster and smooth again. I had to do this on probably about 20% of the cutscenes, the others played fine. You can also adjust your mouse sensitivity in the DosBox settings. You may notice that your mouse cursor moves horizontal faster than vertical, I could not fix this.

You may want to get a pen and paper while playing. When you talk to people in the game, new subjects will appear that you can talk about just like in most point and click games, but in Harvester you cannot click through every subject because sometimes when you pick one subject the others will not be there after. There is a box that says "other" and you can type in subjects to talk about, but you have to remember the exact title of the subject. I chose to write down the subjects each time I talked to someone and then crossed them off after I did each one. That way I can type in the others that disappeared and get to hear all the great dialogue. Try swearing at your mother, lol.

This review has been needing to get done for a long time and it's nice to see more and newer people discover this game especially after that massive discount recently glad you guys are enjoying it. Now let me start off by saying Harvester is NOT for everyone. Do I  myself love this game? Yes I do but for those easily offended or for those faint of heart I suggest staying away although I highly recommend the game it's audience is not aimed at those people but if you are still curious I would say it's worth looking into for sure just be prepared for what you are getting yourself into.

You start off the game with some 90's FMV sequences and the introduction of your main character Steve. Oh what a kidder Steve is along his journey he will uncover who he is and what is the deal with this Stepford Suburbian's town of Harvest. There will be many a zany characters in this such as the soon to be stepdad who loves meat human or otherwise , the gay firemen.....dare I say they are flaming!? , The Wasp Woman and even your own mom be careful on asking her to have sex she just might take you up on that offer......uh.. yeah okay. Anyways the mechanic's are your typical point and click fashion except no real way to get permanently stuck thank goodness but I would recommend saving often. You never know when that Officer who has no legs with PTSD will gun you down and set off the rockets killing you all.

You will soon be introudced to all these characters and the more important ones such as Stephanie your soon to be wife who is in the same situation as you are with no recollection of what happened before or what is going on now and the Sergeant at Arms who is associated with this "lodge" everyone in town is obsessed with. What is the meaning behind it? Well it's your job to find out the Sergeant will task you with multiple things to do to pass the days and uncover the lodge's mysteries. There are multiple endings and some "dead end" endings too so watch out. Overall it's a really fun game with tons of satire , metaphors , violent for the sake of being violent , goofyness cheezy for the sake of being cheezy (and for the plot) so if all of that sounds good and catching STDs from hookers then this game is for you!

13010136.review:
Harvester is a great game, but it's not for everybody.  

It claims to be the "most violent adventure game of all time," but "most disturbing" or "most offensive" might be more appropriate.  As well as exceedingly violent, the game is also homophobic, misogynistic, and generally rife with unpleasantries; be aware that the game is designed as satirical self-parody, intended for consenting adults only.

Concerning gameplay: what begins as an interactive B-movie eventually evolves into something quite different, along the way featuring plenty of tongue-in-cheek commentary on violence and death (within the video game medium and without).  Mature adults will laugh at the game's goofiness and gore, but will also understand the point being made using all the blood and insanity.

Save often, use multiple save files, and expect lots of reloading.

12858351.review:
1996 DOS point and click adventure, Satire/ Horror/ Fantasy/ Sci-Fi.

By todays standards highly flawed and highly recommended.

Cons :
- B grade poor quality FMV.
- Politically incorrect and potentially offensive.
- Occasional illogical puzzle/ item use/ combo common for the genre and time.
- Horrendously janky combat mechanics, primarily confined to the games third and final act.

Pros :
- B grade poor quality FMV.
- Politically incorrect and potentially offensive.
- Especially dark, twisted, amusing and interesting cast of characters.
- A rare ancient gem, the subject matter and themes aren't things you will find explored in contemporary games too often if at all. A relic from a bygone era deserving of its' cult status

The games worst aspect is its combat, no question. The first 2 acts are traditional point and click style with the 3rd heavily incorporating combat additionally. Whilst you CAN kill people in the first 2 acts there aren't many reasons to do so and there are consequences, many of them fail states. So when it came time to unleash I found it a welcome change of pace which added a nice, albeit frustrating at times, survival horror element towards the end. I managed to quite enjoy it despite its shortcomings but I understand why that isn't a popular sentiment. The timing of attacks is mostly luck but choosing the right weapon can make things a lot easier. Also there are opportunities to talk your way around some confrontations.

If you are a horror fan (particularly if you have an eye for satire/ social commentary) and are craving an interesting story (even if, like myself, you aren't overly fond of the point and click genre) you owe it to yourself to pick this up at some point and persevere 'til the bitter end/s.

If you're the type to take the Metacritic score into account I advise you to take note of the disparity between the critical and user reviews.

There's also a GOG version if you'd prefer.

. . . and if you'd like to see a review which mostly echoes my feelings toward Harvester then this LGR review is pretty close but it contains some SPOILERS, so fair warning.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YtjAsQIPauY

12158515.review:
For a game that's mostly remembered for its infamy as "the goriest game of all time" a title it could possibly still hold due to the fortunate lack of baby blinding in more contemporary videogames, Harvester does have a surprising amount of merit despite that.

The dialogue is funny and engaging, and the puzzles - while not particularly mind-blowing - aren't awful and obtuse, and the combat mechanics weren't aggravating to any extent. I almost had fun accidentally punching children in the face when I meant to talk to them. The relatively small overworld map was enjoyable to watch change throughout the game's timeline, and a massive amount of the game is optional - from hidden weapons and rooms to entire areas of the overworld map having absolutely no effect on the plot (The Wasp Woman and Military Base in particular). 

What Harvester tries to be is a dark comedy with a few sobering morals. Age has changed what it is though, from an era where FMVs and basic 3d modelling were standard to one where their very existence is hilariously archaic. 

The game hasn't just become camp, it's become on of the most stupidly camp games you could - and should - ever play. The absurdly gory deaths are no longer shocking moments, they're punchlines - watching the digitized actors dramatically spread eagle on 3d rendered backdrops that could pass for a high school student's school project results is so bad that it's brilliant.

I'd recommend Harvester to anyone who's in for a camp adventure in the vein of watching 13 year olds from yesteryear try to be dark and cool, and doesn't mind always being a kidder, Steve.

Be warned, however, that this isn't a true port - it's DOSBOX. Expect some graphical glitches, minor mechanical fiddly bits, rare but annoying crashes and I did on occasion have a few FMVs refuse to play. Just something to keep in mind.

12013238.review: The game's overall premise, "violent media (television shows, video games, etc.) are causing children to become more violent" might have been true in 1996. Actually the trend of juvenile violence relating to video games has experienced a downward trend since the formation of the ESRB in 1994, so the premise is no longer true (and here in 2014 we can laugh about it). But the overall message is obscured by the game. Its only concern is to get you to play "minor pranks" that will ultimately turn Steve into a serial killer. As the game goes on, it gets more and more ridiculous. The newspaper boy has a pistol that he'll shoot you with if you don't put the newspaper outside (the game even acknowledges the ridiculousness of that), Loomis the sheriff's deputy is beaten with a newspaper like a dog by the sherriff if he catches him beating his meat in a jail cell, a teacher actually beats a child's head in with a baseball bat for asking a question during a nuclear bomb drill, the firefighters are all gay and drive a pink fire truck. The list goes on and on. It was rather nostalgic to play an old point and click style adventure game, but there are far better ones. That's not to say this one is easy, the graphics are so pixellated sometimes it's hard to tell what's what. A grey rectangle in the distance is a drawer that you need to open to get a screwdriver out of. I'd recommend playing this only to see the sheer ridiculousness of the game.

10158949.review:
I was seriously gonna recommend this game... but I didn't.

You start in your bedroom, waking up from a tormented night. Clicking on stuff gives most of the time funny descriptions.
Like "this plastic plant has been recently watered", "this plastic plant is dying" and many other very funny variations. This plastic plant joke will become a true inside joke throughout the game. Then you get to the living room and find a kiddo watching black and white TV. The first dialog happens when you will ask him one of the following questions:
- Who are you?
- Who am I?
- Where am I?
That made me seriously LMFAO.
Well, you got the picture. All the game is like this, with absolutely crazy people, funny dialogs, and incredible stupidity. The acting is bad -- on purpose. However the voices are good.

This game is a point and click adventure parody. But it's not just that. The main story will keep you playing. How comes you know about color TV when those rednecks have no idea it exists? Why don't you remember anything? Why are they... so strange?

You will encounter lots of people in this small town, from a waistless vet protecting a nuclear site, to "feminine" firemen and a teacher that loves to have a ... "goodtime" with little children... This town is completely crazy and you will definitely want to know why and how you did get dragged into this crappy situation.

I had lots of fun the first day in the game. Talking to everyone, blackmailling people and stuff. However, you will get stuck pretty quick, having no idea what you should be doing. Items’ purposes are hard to figure out. I was so stuck that I had to check the walkthrough -- just to know where I was supposed to go. “Damn, yeah, I missed this tiny white pixel which was a light switch”... and so on. Very frustrating.

What really turned me down was the end of the game, which is super lame. All was going fine, with your everyday weird routine, like giving the newspaper in the morning instead of being it given to you, chitchatting with people about commies and gay firemen, peepholing on your GF and watching her undress (eheh). Until you reach... a certain point where the story goes litteraly FUBAR. No more plot, no story, no details anymore. You will just whack you way till the end of the game... and learn the truth. Everything will be explained don't worry. But... that will be super lame.

Overall this game is good for a solid 3/4 of the story. But the plot dissapoints. The story feels so unfinished, what a letdown. There are bugs too, so save often on different slots. The combat system is super  s h i t  but that's meant to be. Some FMV scenes are a bit disturbing which were the cause of the game ban in various countries. But, even though there is an excess of blood and violence, all of that is not serious. We are in a parody all right.

Unfortunately, this was not enough -- for me -- to recommend this game.

10158538.review:
Das mit Abstand schlimmste Game das mir je untergekommen ist. Dies will ich jedoch nicht einfach nur so in den Raum werfen.
Zur Verdeutlichung: Das Spiel verfügt über überspitzte Gewalt. Gut das haben wir in Games wie Phantasmagoria und Konsorten genauso aber... das Schlimme an der Geschichte ist ja, dass das Spiel einem oft nur die Entscheidung zwischen gewalttätigem tot und gewalttätigem tot bzw. in einigen Dingen überhaupt keine Entscheidungsfreiheit lässt. Es behandelt Themen wie Kindermord, Selbstmord, Massensterben etc. ohne jegliche Sensibilität. Und da das nicht schlimm genug ist, muss alles auch noch schön in Sequenzen explizit dargestellt werden. Ein Kind mit Loch im Kopf, dass die Lehrerin zum Spaß reingeschlagen hat- keine Konsequenzen. Der Charakter den man spielt reagiert da nicht weiter drauf. Man selbst tötet (ohne zu viel zu spoilern) und findet auch Leichen... oder muss einer um ihr totes Kind (was uns das Spiel auch wieder unter die Nase halten muss) trauernden Mutter noch das Letzte nehmen was ihr bleibt und ihr Restaurant niederbrennen um im Spiel weiter zu kommen. Das hat noch zur Folge, dass sie sich erhängt (wieder extra in einer absurden Sequenz dargestellt) aber das Spiel wiederum hat keinerlei Sinn für Sensibilität im Bezug auf bestimmte Themen.
Die Gewalt wird entweder verherrlicht oder als "normal" abgetan und der Spieler muss immer wieder einfach mitmachen.
Dabei sind weder die Bewohner (welche teilweise schlimmer sind als die Szenen, da ihre Kommentare das komplette Geschehen noch übler gestalten) noch die eigene Hauptfigur glaubwürdig.
Ich habe das Spiel als Livestream gezockt und kann nur sagen "Finger weg".
Die Zuschauer und ich waren oft kurz davor, das Ganze abzubrechen und haben letzten Endes beschlossen in der Hoffnung vlt. ein ordentliches Ende zu erhalten, die Session durchzuziehen.
Es mag sein das die Locations vielfältig und einfallsreich sind, aber durch die absurden Szenen und erzwungenen, moralisch jedoch nicht zu unterstützenden Handlungen, ist es einfach nur schlecht.
Davon ab lässt das ungenaue Gameplay sehr zu wünschen übrig und durch einige Bugs müssen gelegentlich Screens neu geladen werden oder Zusammenhänge werden einfach weggelassen. 
(manchmal vlt. sogar zum Vorteil, da einige bereits tot, sind ohne das man wieder Hand anzulegen braucht oder sich eine weitere schlechte Splatterszene anschauen muss)

Das Game hätte viel Potential gehabt, hat es aber durch die Umsetzung wirklich komplett in den Sand gesetzt. 
Der Streamchat und ich waren froh, als das Trauerspiel endlich ein Ende gefunden hat und wir wissen, welches Game wir sicherlich nicht noch einmal anrühren werden.
Das Beste ist eigentlich, dass man nach solch einem Machtwerk des brutalen Schunds die wirklich guten Games noch einmal richtig zu schätzen weiß und auch Titel wie Phantasmagoria mit ganz anderen Augen betrachtet.

10149562.review:
Ok recensire questo gioco non è facile: la trama è complicata e sopra le righe, disturbante, mentre il sistema di gioco è arcaico e superato...ma la vera domanda è: nel 2014 esiste qualcosa di lontanamente paragonabile che possa restituire le stesse sensazioni di Harvester? La risposta è semplice: assolutamente no. Non avevo mai giocato a questo gioco prima d'ora e mi sono ritrovato a finirlo dall'inizio alla fine senza riprendere fiato. L'ambientazione è una delle più disturbanti e criptiche mai conceptite e dietro quella finta patina da B-movie, si nasconde un incubo sottile e delirante.
Più si va avanti e più si vuole capire come andrà a finire, più la trama diventa contorta e complessa. Se la prima metà del gioco è un classico punta e clicca neanche troppo ben fatto, la seconda metà è totalmente incentrata sul combattimento e sull'esplorazione e, nonostante il sistema sia quantomai goffo, regala grandi momenti ed un bestiario davvero grottesco e variegato.
Inoltre il gioco vanta dei momenti e delle scene segrete, tra cui numerose morti molto violente da far invidia ad un Dead Space qualunque. Qualche consiglio? Provate a non dare mai il giornale la mattina al bambino o attaccate la donna nella casa con le vespe.
A conti fatti consiglio questo gioco agli amanti dell'horror e del surreale che troveranno una trama complessa ed appagante, con delle scene talmente disgustose e disturbanti che almeno una volta vi volterete dall'altra parte.

9837509.review:
I remember buying this game for $1 (sealed) at a tag sale around 1998 when I was ten years old. While my friend and I thought it was the bloodiest, most disgusting game ever made, I can look back on it now and laugh; the cartoon-y gore is clearly supposed to be over-the-top and played for laughs (see: the "spinal cord" scene on YouTube). Very much in the same vein as Sierra's [b]Phantasmagoria[/b], but with much lower production values.

[b]Harvester[/b] is split into two parts: Discs 1 and 2 are the "adventure" segments which involve running around town and collecting clues, not unlike the first Phantasmagoria (which had much better acting, IMHO). The last disc spins the title off into somewhat of an action sequence in which you climb, floor-by-floor, the mysterious [i]Lodge[/i] building full of total whackos (whom you are given the choice of helping or killing with a variety of tools, including a nail gun, katana or shotgun).

This is just a straight-up emulated port of the MS-DOS version, complete with all the glitches and crashes I experienced fifteen years ago. Do yourself a favor and use the "enchanced" DosBOX program [the second option] from the launcher when playing: it speeds up the loading times during the FMV sequences.

[b]Pros:[/b] Killer music (at least the rock tracks in the Lodge), funny dialogue, interesting ending.
[b]Cons:[/b] Choppy animation, faulty game engine, horrible combat design -- it's a buggy game.

9749597.review:
I remember the FMV genre being an odd novelty in the video game industry which was both amazing and annoying at the same time. Seeing live actors fully interacting within a digital world was fascinating. Unfortunately, the concept was poorly implemented--resulting in all frills and no thrills gameplay. Corpse Killer immediately comes to mind; what a horrible game. Point-and-click adventure seemed best suited for this particular class, and Harvester is a fine example of that. I'm surprised at the level of violence in this game and how it managed to sneak under the radar of sensitive noses.

FMV may be dead, and will probably never return; but I salute the hardwork by programmers to preserve these lost artifacts for future generations.
